column2: Chapter I. The Twin-Verses
column3: Chapter one The Twin Verses
one.

column2: All that we are is the result of what we have thought: it is founded on our thoughts, it is made up of our thoughts.
column3: All that we are is the result of what we have thought: it is founded on our thoughts, it is made up of our thoughts.

column2: If a man speaks or acts with an evil thought, pain follows him, as the wheel follows the foot of the ox that draws the carriage.
column3: If a man speaks or acts with an evil thought, pain follows him, as the wheel follows the foot of the ox that draws the carriage.
two.

column2: All that we are is the result of what we have thought: it is founded on our thoughts, it is made up of our thoughts.
column3: All that we are is the result of what we have thought: it is founded on our thoughts, it is made up of our thoughts.

column2: If a man speaks or acts with a pure thought, happiness follows him, like a shadow that never leaves him.
column3: If a man speaks or acts with a pure thought, happiness follows him, like a shadow that never leaves him.
three.

column2: He abused me, he beat me, he defeated me, he robbed me,--in those who harbour such thoughts hatred will never cease.
column3: He abused me, he beat me, he defeated me, he robbed me,--in those who harbour such thoughts hatred will never cease.
four.

column2: He abused me, he beat me, he defeated me, he robbed me,--in those who do not harbour such thoughts hatred will cease.
column3: He abused me, he beat me, he defeated me, he robbed me,--in those who do not harbour such thoughts hatred will cease.
five.

column2: For hatred does not cease by hatred at any time: hatred ceases by love, this is an old rule.
column3: For hatred does not cease by hatred at any time: hatred ceases by love, this is an old rule.
six.

column2: The world does not know that we must all come to an end here;--but those who know it, their quarrels cease at once.
column3: The world does not know that we must all come to an end here;--but those who know it, their quarrels cease at once.
seven.

column2: He who lives looking for pleasures only, his senses uncontrolled, immoderate in his food, idle, and weak, Mara (the tempter) will certainly overthrow him, as the wind throws down a weak tree.
column3: He who lives looking for pleasures only, his senses uncontrolled, immoderate in his food, idle, and weak, Mara (the tempter) will certainly overthrow him, as the wind throws down a weak tree.
eight.

column2: He who lives without looking for pleasures, his senses well controlled, moderate in his food, faithful and strong, him Mara will certainly not overthrow, any more than the wind throws down a rocky mountain.
column3: He who lives without looking for pleasures, his senses well controlled, moderate in his food, faithful and strong, him Mara will certainly not overthrow, any more than the wind throws down a rocky mountain.
nine.

column2: He who wishes to put on the yellow dress without having cleansed himself from sin, who disregards temperance and truth, is unworthy of the yellow dress.
column3: He who wishes to put on the yellow dress without having cleansed himself from sin, who disregards temperance and truth, is unworthy of the yellow dress.
ten.

column2: But he who has cleansed himself from sin, is well grounded in all virtues, and regards also temperance and truth, he is indeed worthy of the yellow dress.
column3: But he who has cleansed himself from sin, is well grounded in all virtues, and regards also temperance and truth, he is indeed worthy of the yellow dress.
eleven.

column2: They who imagine truth in untruth, and see untruth in truth, never arrive at truth, but follow vain desires.
column3: They who imagine truth in untruth, and see untruth in truth, never arrive at truth, but follow vain desires.
twelve.

column2: They who know truth in truth, and untruth in untruth, arrive at truth, and follow true desires.
column3: They who know truth in truth, and untruth in untruth, arrive at truth, and follow true desires.
thirteen.

column2: As rain breaks through an ill-thatched house, passion will break through an unreflecting mind.
column3: As rain breaks through an ill thatched house, passion will break through an unreflecting mind.
fourteen.

column2: As rain does not break through a well-thatched house, passion will not break through a well-reflecting mind.
column3: As rain does not break through a well thatched house, passion will not break through a well reflecting mind.
fifteen.

column2: The evil-doer mourns in this world, and he mourns in the next; he mourns in both.
column3: The evil doer mourns in this world, and he mourns in the next; he mourns in both.

column2: He mourns and suffers when he sees the evil of his own work.
column3: He mourns and suffers when he sees the evil of his own work.
sixteen.

column2: The virtuous man delights in this world, and he delights in the next; he delights in both.
column3: The virtuous man delights in this world, and he delights in the next; he delights in both.

column2: He delights and rejoices, when he sees the purity of his own work.
column3: He delights and rejoices, when he sees the purity of his own work.
seventeen.

column2: The evil-doer suffers in this world, and he suffers in the next; he suffers in both.
column3: The evil doer suffers in this world, and he suffers in the next; he suffers in both.

column2: He suffers when he thinks of the evil he has done; he suffers more when going on the evil path.
column3: He suffers when he thinks of the evil he has done; he suffers more when going on the evil path.
eighteen.

column2: The virtuous man is happy in this world, and he is happy in the next; he is happy in both.
column3: The virtuous man is happy in this world, and he is happy in the next; he is happy in both.

column2: He is happy when he thinks of the good he has done; he is still more happy when going on the good path.
column3: He is happy when he thinks of the good he has done; he is still more happy when going on the good path.
nineteen.

column2: The thoughtless man, even if he can recite a large portion (of the law), but is not a doer of it, has no share in the priesthood, but is like a cowherd counting the cows of others.
column3: The thoughtless man, even if he can recite a large portion (of the law), but is not a doer of it, has no share in the priesthood, but is like a cowherd counting the cows of others.
twenty.

column2: The follower of the law, even if he can recite only a small portion (of the law), but, having forsaken passion and hatred and foolishness, possesses true knowledge and serenity of mind, he, caring for nothing in this world or that to come, has indeed a share in the priesthood.
column3: The follower of the law, even if he can recite only a small portion (of the law), but, having forsaken passion and hatred and foolishness, possesses true knowledge and serenity of mind, he, caring for nothing in this world or that to come, has indeed a share in the priesthood.

column2: Chapter II.
column3: Chapter two.

column2: On Earnestness
column3: On Earnestness
twenty one.

column2: Earnestness is the path of immortality (Nirvana), thoughtlessness the path of death.
column3: Earnestness is the path of immortality (Nirvana), thoughtlessness the path of death.

column2: Those who are in earnest do not die, those who are thoughtless are as if dead already.
column3: Those who are in earnest do not die, those who are thoughtless are as if dead already.
twenty two.

column2: Those who are advanced in earnestness, having understood this clearly, delight in earnestness, and rejoice in the knowledge of the Ariyas (the elect).
column3: Those who are advanced in earnestness, having understood this clearly, delight in earnestness, and rejoice in the knowledge of the Ariyas (the elect).
twenty three.

column2: These wise people, meditative, steady, always possessed of strong powers, attain to Nirvana, the highest happiness.
column3: These wise people, meditative, steady, always possessed of strong powers, attain to Nirvana, the highest happiness.
twenty four.

column2: If an earnest person has roused himself, if he is not forgetful, if his deeds are pure, if he acts with consideration, if he restrains himself, and lives according to law,--then his glory will increase.
column3: If an earnest person has roused himself, if he is not forgetful, if his deeds are pure, if he acts with consideration, if he restrains himself, and lives according to law,--then his glory will increase.
twenty five.

column2: By rousing himself, by earnestness, by restraint and control, the wise man may make for himself an island which no flood can overwhelm.
column3: By rousing himself, by earnestness, by restraint and control, the wise man may make for himself an island which no flood can overwhelm.
twenty six.

column2: Fools follow after vanity, men of evil wisdom.
column3: Fools follow after vanity, men of evil wisdom.

column2: The wise man keeps earnestness as his best jewel.
column3: The wise man keeps earnestness as his best jewel.
twenty seven.

column2: Follow not after vanity, nor after the enjoyment of love and lust! He who is earnest and meditative, obtains ample joy.
column3: Follow not after vanity, nor after the enjoyment of love and lust! He who is earnest and meditative, obtains ample joy.
twenty eight.

column2: When the learned man drives away vanity by earnestness, he, the wise, climbing the terraced heights of wisdom, looks down upon the fools, serene he looks upon the toiling crowd, as one that stands on a mountain looks down upon them that stand upon the plain.
column3: When the learned man drives away vanity by earnestness, he, the wise, climbing the terraced heights of wisdom, looks down upon the fools, serene he looks upon the toiling crowd, as one that stands on a mountain looks down upon them that stand upon the plain.
twenty nine.

column2: Earnest among the thoughtless, awake among the sleepers, the wise man advances like a racer, leaving behind the hack.
column3: Earnest among the thoughtless, awake among the sleepers, the wise man advances like a racer, leaving behind the hack.
thirty.

column2: By earnestness did Maghavan (Indra) rise to the lordship of the gods.
column3: By earnestness did Maghavan (Indra) rise to the lordship of the gods.

column2: People praise earnestness; thoughtlessness is always blamed.
column3: People praise earnestness; thoughtlessness is always blamed.
thirty one.

column2: A Bhikshu (mendicant) who delights in earnestness, who looks with fear on thoughtlessness, moves about like fire, burning all his fetters, small or large.
column3: A Bhikshu (mendicant) who delights in earnestness, who looks with fear on thoughtlessness, moves about like fire, burning all his fetters, small or large.
thirty two.

column2: A Bhikshu (mendicant) who delights in reflection, who looks with fear on thoughtlessness, cannot fall away (from his perfect state)--he is close upon Nirvana.
column3: A Bhikshu (mendicant) who delights in reflection, who looks with fear on thoughtlessness, cannot fall away (from his perfect state)--he is close upon Nirvana.

column2: Chapter III.
column3: Chapter three.

column2: Thought
column3: Thought
thirty three.

column2: As a fletcher makes straight his arrow, a wise man makes straight his trembling and unsteady thought, which is difficult to guard, difficult to hold back.
column3: As a fletcher makes straight his arrow, a wise man makes straight his trembling and unsteady thought, which is difficult to guard, difficult to hold back.
thirty four.

column2: As a fish taken from his watery home and thrown on dry ground, our thought trembles all over in order to escape the dominion of Mara (the tempter).
column3: As a fish taken from his watery home and thrown on dry ground, our thought trembles all over in order to escape the dominion of Mara (the tempter).
thirty five.

column2: It is good to tame the mind, which is difficult to hold in and flighty, rushing wherever it listeth; a tamed mind brings happiness.
column3: It is good to tame the mind, which is difficult to hold in and flighty, rushing wherever it listeth; a tamed mind brings happiness.
thirty six.

column2: Let the wise man guard his thoughts, for they are difficult to perceive, very artful, and they rush wherever they list: thoughts well guarded bring happiness.
column3: Let the wise man guard his thoughts, for they are difficult to perceive, very artful, and they rush wherever they list: thoughts well guarded bring happiness.
thirty seven.

column2: Those who bridle their mind which travels far, moves about alone, is without a body, and hides in the chamber (of the heart), will be free from the bonds of Mara (the tempter).
column3: Those who bridle their mind which travels far, moves about alone, is without a body, and hides in the chamber (of the heart), will be free from the bonds of Mara (the tempter).
thirty eight.

column2: If a man's thoughts are unsteady, if he does not know the true law, if his peace of mind is troubled, his knowledge will never be perfect.
column3: If a man's thoughts are unsteady, if he does not know the true law, if his peace of mind is troubled, his knowledge will never be perfect.
thirty nine.

column2: If a man's thoughts are not dissipated, if his mind is not perplexed, if he has ceased to think of good or evil, then there is no fear for him while he is watchful.
column3: If a man's thoughts are not dissipated, if his mind is not perplexed, if he has ceased to think of good or evil, then there is no fear for him while he is watchful.
forty.

column2: Knowing that this body is (fragile) like a jar, and making this thought firm like a fortress, one should attack Mara (the tempter) with the weapon of knowledge, one should watch him when conquered, and should never rest.
column3: Knowing that this body is (fragile) like a jar, and making this thought firm like a fortress, one should attack Mara (the tempter) with the weapon of knowledge, one should watch him when conquered, and should never rest.
forty one.

column2: Before long, alas!
column3: Before long, alas!

column2: this body will lie on the earth, despised, without understanding, like a useless log.
column3: this body will lie on the earth, despised, without understanding, like a useless log.
forty two.

column2: Whatever a hater may do to a hater, or an enemy to an enemy, a wrongly-directed mind will do us greater mischief.
column3: Whatever a hater may do to a hater, or an enemy to an enemy, a wrongly directed mind will do us greater mischief.
forty three.

column2: Not a mother, not a father will do so much, nor any other relative; a well-directed mind will do us greater service.
column3: Not a mother, not a father will do so much, nor any other relative; a well directed mind will do us greater service.

column2: Chapter IV.
column3: Chapter four.

column2: Flowers
column3: Flowers
forty four.

column2: Who shall overcome this earth, and the world of Yama (the lord of the departed), and the world of the gods?
column3: Who shall overcome this earth, and the world of Yama (the lord of the departed), and the world of the gods?

column2: Who shall find out the plainly shown path of virtue, as a clever man finds out the (right) flower?
column3: Who shall find out the plainly shown path of virtue, as a clever man finds out the (right) flower?
forty five.

column2: The disciple will overcome the earth, and the world of Yama, and the world of the gods.
column3: The disciple will overcome the earth, and the world of Yama, and the world of the gods.

column2: The disciple will find out the plainly shown path of virtue, as a clever man finds out the (right) flower.
column3: The disciple will find out the plainly shown path of virtue, as a clever man finds out the (right) flower.
forty six.

column2: He who knows that this body is like froth, and has learnt that it is as unsubstantial as a mirage, will break the flower-pointed arrow of Mara, and never see the king of death.
column3: He who knows that this body is like froth, and has learnt that it is as unsubstantial as a mirage, will break the flower pointed arrow of Mara, and never see the king of death.
forty seven.

column2: Death carries off a man who is gathering flowers and whose mind is distracted, as a flood carries off a sleeping village.
column3: Death carries off a man who is gathering flowers and whose mind is distracted, as a flood carries off a sleeping village.
forty eight.

column2: Death subdues a man who is gathering flowers, and whose mind is distracted, before he is satiated in his pleasures.
column3: Death subdues a man who is gathering flowers, and whose mind is distracted, before he is satiated in his pleasures.
forty nine.

column2: As the bee collects nectar and departs without injuring the flower, or its colour or scent, so let a sage dwell in his village.
column3: As the bee collects nectar and departs without injuring the flower, or its colour or scent, so let a sage dwell in his village.
fifty.

column2: Not the perversities of others, not their sins of commission or omission, but his own misdeeds and negligences should a sage take notice of.
column3: Not the perversities of others, not their sins of commission or omission, but his own misdeeds and negligences should a sage take notice of.
fifty one.

column2: Like a beautiful flower, full of colour, but without scent, are the fine but fruitless words of him who does not act accordingly.
column3: Like a beautiful flower, full of colour, but without scent, are the fine but fruitless words of him who does not act accordingly.
fifty two.

column2: But, like a beautiful flower, full of colour and full of scent, are the fine and fruitful words of him who acts accordingly.
column3: But, like a beautiful flower, full of colour and full of scent, are the fine and fruitful words of him who acts accordingly.
fifty three.

column2: As many kinds of wreaths can be made from a heap of flowers, so many good things may be achieved by a mortal when once he is born.
column3: As many kinds of wreaths can be made from a heap of flowers, so many good things may be achieved by a mortal when once he is born.
fifty four.

column2: The scent of flowers does not travel against the wind, nor (that of) sandal-wood, or of Tagara and Mallika flowers; but the odour of good people travels even against the wind; a good man pervades every place.
column3: The scent of flowers does not travel against the wind, nor (that of) sandal wood, or of Tagara and Mallika flowers; but the odour of good people travels even against the wind; a good man pervades every place.
fifty five.

column2: Sandal-wood or Tagara, a lotus-flower, or a Vassiki, among these sorts of perfumes, the perfume of virtue is unsurpassed.
column3: Sandal wood or Tagara, a lotus flower, or a Vassiki, among these sorts of perfumes, the perfume of virtue is unsurpassed.
fifty six.

column2: Mean is the scent that comes from Tagara and sandal-wood;--the perfume of those who possess virtue rises up to the gods as the highest.
column3: Mean is the scent that comes from Tagara and sandal wood;--the perfume of those who possess virtue rises up to the gods as the highest.
fifty seven.

column2: Of the people who possess these virtues, who live without thoughtlessness, and who are emancipated through true knowledge, Mara, the tempter, never finds the way.
column3: Of the people who possess these virtues, who live without thoughtlessness, and who are emancipated through true knowledge, Mara, the tempter, never finds the way.
fifty eight, fifty nine.

column2: As on a heap of rubbish cast upon the highway the lily will grow full of sweet perfume and delight, thus the disciple of the truly enlightened Buddha shines forth by his knowledge among those who are like rubbish, among the people that walk in darkness.
column3: As on a heap of rubbish cast upon the highway the lily will grow full of sweet perfume and delight, thus the disciple of the truly enlightened Buddha shines forth by his knowledge among those who are like rubbish, among the people that walk in darkness.
